text: The Spingarn Medal is awarded annually by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) for outstanding achievement by an African American. The award was created in 1914 by Joel Elias Spingarn, chairman of the Board of Directors of the NAACP. It was first awarded to biologist Ernest E. Just in 1915. The gold medal is valued at $100, and Spingarn left $20,000 in his will for the NAACP to continue giving it indefinitely. ==List of award winners== Year Picture Name Rationale 1915 "Head of Physiology, Howard University Medical School for research in biology." 1916 "Services in organizing the Liberian Constabulary and roads in the Republic of Liberia." 1917 "Excellence in the field of creative music." 1918 "Distinguished achievements in literature." 1919 "U.S. Consul in Santo Domingo; President of American Negro Academy; for seventy years of distinguished service to his race and country." 1920 "Author, Editor Crisis Magazine; founding and calling of Pan-African Congress." 1921 "Notable performance in the title role of The Emperor Jones and for excellence as an actor." 1922 "Former President of the National Association of Colored Women and for continued service to women of color." 1923 "Head of Department of Research and Director of the Experiment Station of Tuskegee Inst.
